item.title: Airstrikes by Turkey Hit 3 ISIS Targets in Syria
item.description: The strikes came a day after Turkey’s first reported direct combat with the Islamic State and its granting American warplanes permission to conduct strikes against the group from two of its air bases.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The funeral in Gaziantep, Turkey, on Friday of a Turkish soldier who died in combat with Islamic State militants on the Syrian border.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: First Black Leader of South Africa’s Opposition Seeks to Unseat the A.N.C.
item.description: Mmusi Maimane, the new head of the Democratic Alliance, is trying to draw middle-class blacks away from the African National Congress and keep his party’s core supporters, who are white.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Mmusi Maimane, the leader of the Democratic Alliance, the South African opposition party, spoke to supporters in Soweto last month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ma Xue on Why China Has Embraced Korean TV
item.description: Ms. Ma, a culture critic, TV host and producer, helps companies create television shows for the Chinese market.
item.category: My Love From Another Star (TV Program)
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Ma Xue helps companies create television shows for the Chinese market.

item.title: Trial of Chinese Rights Campaigners on Subversion Charges Continues
item.description: The proceedings in the southern city of Guangzhou against the three defendants, who have been held for over a year, resumed after a monthlong halt.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Doctors, Under Strain and Threat, Call for Support in Video
item.description: A new compilation of interviews with Chinese doctors seeks to shed light on the daily burdens and joys of a profession struggling with long hours, low pay and the threat of violence from patients and their families.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Hospital workers protested against attacks on medical personnel outside No. 1 People's Hospital in Wenling, Zhejiang Province, on Oct. 28, 2013, after a man stabbed three doctors, killing one. The sign on the left says: "Restore my dignity."

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Algeria’s Invisible Arab
item.description: Conflict is illuminated as the nameless murder victim of Camus's "The Stranger" becomes a human being in a new novel.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Malaysia Suspends 2 Newspapers Covering Scandal at State-Owned Fund
item.description: The parent company of the two publications said the order was in response to coverage of possible fraud involving the fund, 1Malaysia Development Berhad.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: The China Factor: China’s Global Ambitions, With Loans and Strings Attached
item.description: The country has invested billions in Ecuador and elsewhere, using its economic clout to win diplomatic allies and secure natural resources around the world.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Ivan Kashinsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Water pipes set aside near where Ecuador wants a Chinese oil company to build a giant refinery, outside the port of Manta. China has invested heavily in overseas oil projects.

item.title: Obama to Push U.S. Trade in Kenya as China’s Role Grows
item.description: Central agreements may help shape a major deal for private investment in Kenya’s infrastructure, while also helping mend relations between governments.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: American flags were sold on the street in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, in anticipation of President Obama's arrival on Friday.

item.title: Al Qaeda’s Chief of Bombing Attacks Died in U.S. Strike, Pentagon Says
item.description: Abu Khalil al-Sudani, said to have directed suicide bombings and other operations with explosives, was killed on July 11 in Afghanistan, the military reported.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Letter From Europe: Greek Plan Stirs Memories in Germany
item.description: For many Germans, the arguments against repeating the Treuhand in Greece are overwhelming.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Mexican Panel Criticizes Inquiry in Missing Students Case
item.description: Investigators did not pursue numerous leads before concluding that the students had been arrested and then killed by a gang, a human rights group said.
item.category: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Kerry Defends Iran Nuclear Deal Before Skeptical Senate
item.description: If the deal is not put into effect, the secretary of state said, Iran will get a “a great big green light” to go forward with its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Energy Secretary Ernest J. Moniz joined two other cabinet secretaries in the effort to persuade skeptical senators to back the Iran nuclear deal, and he found some support — or at least less hostility — among Democrats.

item.title: U.S. Jets to Use Turkish Bases in War on ISIS
item.description: The development, described by the Americans as a “game changer,” came as Turkish forces engaged in the first direct combat with ISIS on the Syrian border.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Turkish tanks near the Syrian border, where Turkish forces struck at ISIS after an attack.

item.title: Rosanne Klass, Writer and Advocate for the Afghan People, Dies at 86
item.description: Ms. Klass, a writer and human rights advocate, taught English in rural Afghan schools and later became the director of the Afghanistan Information Center.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Rebels Ousted From a Port City, Officials Say
item.description: Saudi-backed Yemeni troops took full control of Aden from Shiite rebels, and the airport reopened.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Owen Chadwick, Eminent Historian of Christianity, Dies at 99
item.description: “The Reformation” (1964), one of two volumes Professor Chadwick wrote for The Penguin History of the Church, was required reading in colleges for decades.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Helicopters Sent to Jordan for Border Security
item.description: Jordan received 16 Cobra combat helicopters to help it fend off insurgents on the Syrian and Iraqi borders.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Boy Says He Tried to Incite a Terrorist Attack
item.description: The 15-year-old pleaded guilty to instigating a plan to attack against police officers in Australia.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Dozens of Migrants Feared Drowned Near Libya
item.description: As many as 40 people fleeing Africa died when their inflatable boat sank. Eighty people were reported rescued.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
